bibl.title: John Matthews v. Henry M. White. correspondents
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: U.S. DEPARTMENT OF LABOR Immigration Service
37012/600 Seattle, Washington, still in the possession of the alien at the time of hearing.

After arriving in the United States he proceeded to Alaska, where he worked approximately two months before his arrest. He was convicted in the United States District Court, Third Division of Alaska, on a charge of sending obscene matter through January 15, 1921.
SUMMARY AND FINDINGS In the case of John Matthews.

The alien was arrested on a departmental warrant, charging that he had been sentenced subsequent to the passage of the act of February 15, 1917, to imprisonment for a term of one year or more, because of conviction in this country of a crime involving moral turpitude, committed within five years after his entry into the United States, and with the additional charge that he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry. The alien was not represented by counsel.

The record shows that he is 28 years of age; that he was born in Ukrainian, Austria, and that he claims to have landed at either St. Johns, N.B., or Halifax, N.S., he could not be positive which, in either the year 1906 or 1907, sailing from Antwerp, Belgium, on the SS "Montezuma", his destination at a that time, according to his story, being New York; that he proceeded to New York, remained there a short while, and returned to Canada, going to Montreal, thence to Ottowa; that he lived in Canada continuously until August 31, 1919 when he applied for admission to the United States at the port of Victoria, B.C., and was admitted as a visitor, paying head tax, and being given head tax refund receipt No.14188. This receipt was the mail, and was sentenced May 4, 1920, to serve a term of one year in the Federal Penitentiary at McNeil Island.

After considering the testimony adduced in this case I find that John Matthews is an alien, that he entered the United States through the port of Victoria, B.C., August 31, 1919; that he was at the time a person likely to become a public charge, and that he has been sentenced subsequent to the passage of the act of February 5, 1917, to imprisonment for a term of one year or more, because of his conviction in this country of a crime involving moral turpitude committed within five years after his entry to the United States, and I therefore respectfully recommend that he be ordered deported to the country whence he came, or of which he is a citizen or subject, in conformity with law.
The alien's description is as follows, Age 28 years; height 5'61/4, weight 189 pounds; hair dark brown; eyes hazel gray, complexion medium.
